image.altText: A green globe with a shielf with a cross in it in front of a laptop computer.

items.synopsis: A data "incident" report, obtained by the ABC through freedom of information, reveals the NT Government breached the privacy of thousands of public health patients.

title.children: 'How far have they spread?': Patients impacted by NT health record data breach

image.altText: Tina Turner belting into a microphone. She has short, curly blond hair and red lipstick. She's wearing a black lace chemise.

items.synopsis: The American-born singer left a hard scrabble farming community to become one of the top recording artists of all time.

title.children: 'Queen of Rock 'n' Roll' Tina Turner dies aged 83

image.altText: An older man sits with his hands clasped at a table on a veranda, smiling.

items.synopsis: Colin Brett's family led a class action against the federal government's 2011 live export ban. Industry figures say Mr Brett leaves a "tremendous legacy".

title.children: 'True gentleman' of NT cattle industry remembered for his 'quiet strength' after death at 83

image.altText: an elderly woman looking at the camera

items.synopsis: A police officer is facing several charges after Mrs Nowland was tasered during an incident at a nursing home in New South Wales last week.

title.children: Clare Nowland, 95-year-old great-grandmother tasered at Cooma nursing home, dies

image.altText: Mojib Rahman stands on a rooftop looking out to the horizon.

items.synopsis: Mojib Rahman went from scam victim to "money mule", as he tried to recover his lost funds. Now his bank has apologised for the way it handled his case.

title.children: Mojib got caught up in a scam, then his bank seized $100k from his accounts

image.altText: Jess and Jackie Morecroft stand in the driveway of their home.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for the state have lodged an appeal against a monetary order made earlier this year, arguing the judge who approved the $2.7 million payout got it wrong.

title.children: 'Cruel and unjust': Queensland government to appeal $2.7m payout for mortgage fraud victims

image.altText: a young man smiling in his apartment

items.synopsis: When migrant workers get exploited, all Australians pay the price with potentially lower wages. The federal government is looking to reform visa rules to make it easier for vulnerable migrants to speak out.

title.children: Sajad reckons he was underpaid $20,000 by employers and says many migrants like him are being ripped off

image.altText: Big Mango tourist attraction

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: The Big Mango's big internet milestone, and Ron DeSantis confirms US presidential run. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has officially entered the 2024 US presidential race. He's stepping into a crowded Republican primary contest which will test his national appeal as an outspoken cultural conservative and the GOP's willingness to move on from former president Donald Trump — who is also running for presidnet. The 44-year-old DeSantis revealed his decision in a Federal Election Commission filing before an online conversation with Twitter CEO Elon Musk, which is expected to take place around 8am AEST this morning. DeSantis is considered to be Trump's strongest Republican rival even as the governor faces questions about his readiness for the national stage.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ron DeSantis confirms he's running against Trump for US president

props.alt: Three men, one with white hair, sit next to each other at a table, wearing suits and ties

children.content: (AP: Evan Vucci)
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has officially entered the 2024 US presidential race.
He's stepping into
a crowded Republican primary contest
which will test his national appeal as
an outspoken cultural conservative
and the GOP's willingness to move on from former president Donald Trump — who is also running for presidnet.
The 44-year-old DeSantis revealed his decision in a Federal Election Commission filing before an online conversation with Twitter CEO Elon Musk, which is
expected to take place around 8am AEST this morning
DeSantis is considered to be Trump's strongest Republican rival even as the governor faces questions about his readiness for the national stage.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: American rapper Fetty Wap has been sentenced to six years in prison for his role in a New York-based drug trafficking scheme. The artist, whose legal name is Willie Maxwell, apologised for his actions and told a court he was "exactly where I'm supposed to be" before the sentencing. The Trap Queen rapper pleaded guilty in August 2022 to a conspiracy drug charge that carried a mandatory minimum sentence of five years. Maxwell told US District Judge Joanna Seybert, "Me being selfish in my pride put me in this position today." His lawyers had suggested he turned to selling drugs because of financial hardship brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic. Maxwell was arrested in October 2021 on charges of participating in a conspiracy to smuggle large amounts of heroin, fentanyl and other drugs into the New York City area.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rapper Fetty Wap handed prison sentence over drug trafficking scheme

props.alt: Rapper Fetty Wap, wearing a bandana, looks at the camera on a Grammys red carpet

children.content: (AP: John Salangsang/Invision)
American rapper Fetty Wap has been
sentenced to six years in prison
for his role in a New York-based drug trafficking scheme.
The artist, whose legal name is Willie Maxwell, apologised for his actions and told a court he was "exactly where I'm supposed to be" before the sentencing.
The Trap Queen rapper pleaded guilty in August 2022 to a conspiracy drug charge that
carried a mandatory minimum sentence of five years
Maxwell told US District Judge Joanna Seybert, "Me being selfish in my pride put me in this position today."
His lawyers had suggested he turned to selling drugs because of financial hardship brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Maxwell was arrested in October 2021 on charges of participating in a conspiracy to smuggle large amounts of heroin, fentanyl and other drugs into the New York City area.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One of Australia's premier 'big things' and road trip spots, the Big Mango in the Queensland town of Bowen, celebrates its 21st birthday today. To mark the occasion, its juicy image has been splashed across the Google homepage as today's Google Doodle. Here's what it looks like: "In 2002, the town of Bowen, in North Queensland, built a hefty tribute to their world-famous mangoes and prosperous fruit orchards," Google says in a blog post about the Doodle. "The Big Mango is on the Bruce Highway, just 5km south of the town of Bowen. The town is also known as the 'salad bowl of the north' as they also grow tomatoes, capsicums and other vegetables." The Big Mango weighs more than five tonnes and stands 10 metres tall. Happy birthday, you big beautiful bastard.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: News Australia is searching for: The Big Mango

children.content: One of Australia's premier 'big things' and road trip spots, the Big Mango in the Queensland town of Bowen,
celebrates its 21st birthday today

props.alt: Bowen's Big Mango, among trees, with a man standing near it

children.content: (Supplied: Bowen Tourist Information Centre)
To mark the occasion, its juicy image has been splashed across the Google homepage as today's Google Doodle.
Here's what it looks like:

props.alt: A claymation version of The Big Mango, in front of the Google logo

children.content: (Google)
"In 2002, the town of Bowen, in North Queensland, built a hefty tribute to their world-famous mangoes and prosperous fruit orchards," Google says in a blog post about the Doodle.
"The Big Mango is on the Bruce Highway, just 5km south of the town of Bowen. The town is also known as the 'salad bowl of the north' as they also grow tomatoes, capsicums and other vegetables."
The Big Mango
weighs more than five tonnes and stands 10 metres tall
Happy birthday, you big beautiful bastard.

image.altText: UniSC nursing student Poonam Chaudhary assessing a patient

items.synopsis: Australia's aged care sector has long struggled with employee retention. But unstable revenue, COVID, inflation and reforms are other crises that are bleeding the industry dry.

title.children: The latest budget will provide over $11 billion to aged care workers. It might not be enough to save the sector

image.altText: Peter Dutton Budget reply

items.synopsis: The number of Liberals now supporting the Voice is difficult to discern and the mood among those few who are still publicly on board has turned to dismay following Peter Dutton's full-scale denunciation of the Voice proposal, which went much further than many were expecting, writes David Speers.

title.children: Dutton is now engaged in a boots-and-all take-down of the Voice

image.altText: A composite image shows Labor senator Malarndirri McCarthy and independent senator Lidia Thorpe.

items.synopsis: Labor frontbencher Malarndirri McCarthy calls a fellow Indigenous senator a "disgrace to your people" in a fiery exchange about funding for First Nations initiatives at Senate estimates.

title.children: 'A disgrace to your people': Senators McCarthy and Thorpe clash over 'black money' funding NT police

image.altText: A graphic shows young people at a cinema, while a PG rating hovers over them.

items.synopsis: Australia's classification board will now be able to advise movie-goers about a much wider range of content, from very mild slapstick violence to mental health themes to strong animal cruelty.

title.children: Australians are about to be given much more information on the movies they're going to watch

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin leaves a cemetery. He is bald and stares at the camera from a distance.

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin says the children of Russian elites are sunning themselves while ordinary people watch their kids come home in zinc coffins, calling for martial law and for Moscow to prepare for "an arduous war".

title.children: Wagner mercenary group chief warns Russia faces revolution, says 20,000 fighters died in Bakhmut

image.altText: Snow on a city

items.synopsis: Some surprising locations outside the Australian Alps have seen snow, but stories of falls in our major cities might actually be white lies, writes the ABC's meteorologist Tom Saunders.

title.children: Where has snow fallen in Australia outside of the alpine regions?

image.altText: A satellite view of a volcano spewing a plume of ash into the atmosphere

items.synopsis: The Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano eruption last year was so powerful it created a "super plasma bubble" in the upper atmosphere over northern Australia, likely disrupting precise GPS for hours.

title.children: How the Tongan volcano eruption disrupted precise GPS technology as far away as Townsville

image.altText: A close-up of a corporate pwc logo on a reflective glass building panel.

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police (AFP) launches a criminal investigation into a former executive of consulting firm PwC, after he used confidential Treasury information to benefit the firm's client base.

title.children: AFP investigating former PwC executive over using confidential Treasury information

image.altText: Sophie with blond hair wearing matching light blue dress and hat.

items.synopsis: An elderly woman who was struck two weeks ago by a police motorcycle escorting Sophie, the Duchess of Edinburgh in London, dies.

title.children: Duchess of Edinburgh 'deeply saddened' after woman, 81, hit by royal escort dies

image.altText: Simone wears a hot pink shirt, blue & white blazer & black glasses, standing behind a shop counter holding a brown, paper bag an

items.synopsis: Like many Australians, Simone Erdedi became depressed and anxious during COVID-19 lockdowns. With help from her community, she's back to thriving and ready to empower others.

title.children: Simone juggles social media stardom and two jobs. It hasn't been an easy road

image.altText: A man with apparatus on his head stands next to four researchers with walker in front of him.

items.synopsis: After more than a decade of work by researchers in France and Switzerland, a paralysed man has regained the ability to walk naturally using only his thoughts.

title.children: Paralysed man walks using only his thoughts for the first time in scientific breakthrough

image.altText: Two senior women stand with hand around each others' shoulders.

items.synopsis: A funding anomaly means patients are being hit with thousands in out-of-pocket costs. Now 12,000 people are calling for change.

title.children: Amey had to pay almost $5,000 upfront for a cancer consult. Now she's taking the fight to parliament

image.altText: A white man in a navy polo shirt smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: Andrew Spira's lawyers argued he was "deranged" when he allegedly lodged an application for a passport at the Darwin passport office, telling officials his old one had been stolen when in fact it had been surrendered to police in NSW.

title.children: Sydney entrepreneur detained in NT after allegedly attempting to flee overseas with illegal passport

image.altText: A large contingent of police in a car park next to a police vehicle.

items.synopsis: A 15-year-old boy is taken into custody, and two rifles seized, after he allegedly fired shots into a Perth school, sending the college and nearby businesses into lockdown.

title.children: Police shocked after teen allegedly fires shots into Perth school in 'terrible circumstances'

image.altText: Police with hammers and chisels work to free the hand of an activist sitting with hi-vis orange vest with hand glued to road.

items.synopsis: Police have searched 15 properties and prosecutors are investigating seven suspects aged between 22 and 38 on suspicion of forming or backing a criminal organisation, police said.

title.children: German police raid climate activists who blocked traffic

image.altText: A young black woman with red-toned dreadlocked hair is pictured under the sea, holding a fork. A flounder fish is at her side.

items.synopsis: Making her feature film debut, 23-year-old pop star Halle Bailey is the face of Ariel for a new generation and her performance easily outshines her seasoned co-stars.

title.children: When the new Little Mermaid was cast it caused a stir. She's the best thing about the remake

image.altText: Smoke rising from two locations with mosque pictured in the middle

items.synopsis: Clashes between rival military factions have broke out, threatening to shatter a fragile ceasefire designed to allow for the delivery of aid.

title.children: More than 1.3 million displaced in Sudan as army fighter jet reportedly downed near Khartoum

image.altText: An ACT police officer in uniform walks outside a building.

items.synopsis: Detective Superintendent Scott Moller tells an ACT board of inquiry that he was sexually assaulted 45 years ago.

title.children: Lead investigator into Brittany Higgins's rape allegation reveals he is survivor of sexual assault

image.altText: David Anderson reacting to questions at Senate Estimates. He is a balding white man with blue eyes, wearing a blue suit.

items.synopsis: ABC executives have indicated they want to work with other media platforms to try and tackle racist abuse of their staff.

title.children: 'We've fallen short': ABC boss says broadcaster will work with other media companies to end racist abuse of staff

image.altText: Lines of men sitting inside barbed wire wearing identical blue uniforms.

items.synopsis: Australia imports more than $25 billion in goods that may have used modern slavery, and for the first time solar panels are one of the most valuable, according to a human rights group funded by Andrew Forrest.

title.children: Scourge of slavery looms large as Forrest calls out Australia's solar supply chains

image.altText: A road bridge submerged in floodwater with boats and people being rescued

items.synopsis: A national flood management conference has been told governments need to look at where houses are being as well as how they are being constructed.

title.children: Future of 'unprecedented' floods, but town planning might save us, researcher says

image.altText: Man with Tasmanian giant freshwater crayfish.

items.synopsis: The endangered Tasmanian crustacean risks becoming roadkill when it chooses to climb creek banks instead of taking a safer path through culverts, puzzling observers.

title.children: Why did the giant crayfish cross the road? Conservationists want to know — and stop it

image.altText: A surveillance camera sits on a utility pole, with the top of a Russian orthodox church in the background.

items.synopsis: It's increasingly difficult for many Russians to evade authorities, with the government actively monitoring social media accounts and using surveillance cameras against activists.

title.children: 'The cyber gulag': How Russia tracks, censors and controls its citizens

image.altText: Caitlin Bourke wearing her clinical scrubs leaning her crossed arms over her bed

items.synopsis: Students studying to become health professionals are increasingly struggling with the demands of unpaid placements as inflation rises.

title.children: Caitlin is doing unpaid placements across 24 weeks. She turns to buy now, pay later providers to afford food
